sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews now. I'm Helena Humphrey. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Scores are killed and injured in a bombing of a Kabul mosque.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: As yet, no one's claimed responsibility for the blast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: UN Chief Antonia Guterres is in Ukraine for talks with President Zelensky and Turkish President Erdogan amid calls for urgent UN access to inspect the Zaporizhia nuclear plant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And the leaders of Kosovo and Serbia are meeting in Brussels for EU-mediated talks aimed at avoiding renewed conflict after a recent flare-up in tensions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: A Sunni mosque in the Afghan capital Kabul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Scene of a bombing during evening prayers last night, in which at least 21 people died, including a prominent cleric.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As men carry out the casket of one of the victims, police say the death toll will likely rise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: About 33 others were wounded in the blast, including several children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It was evening prayer time and I was attending prayers with others when the explosion happened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It was a very powerful explosion inside the mosque.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, which is the latest since the Taliban seized power again last year the so-called Islamic State groups local affiliate has stepped up attacks targeting the Taliban and civilians following the withdrawal last August of US and NATO troops Turkish president

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Recep Tayyip Erdogan is meeting Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the western city of Lviv today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The Turkish president, along with the UN, was instrumental in negotiating an end to the Russian blockade of Black Sea ports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But at the same time, ties between Turkey and Russia are growing closer, prompting many to ask what is the Turkish president's strategy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: With me now is Son Turkish president's strategy. Well with me now is Sona Chaptay and in his most recent book, A Sultan in Autumn, he offers his insights on the next phase of Erdogan's rule. He's also the director of the Turkish research program at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. Great to have you with us, thank you for taking the time. Thank you. Now Erdogan appears to be walking this diplomatic tightrope, I guess, in real time right now between Russia, between Ukraine. But I guess the question is, ultimately, what is he looking to achieve? So I would say Turkey's Ukraine war policy really needs to be fleshed out. On the one hand, Turkey supports Ukraine militarily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: On the other hand, Turkey keeps ties with Russia open economically. And I think the latter part has a lot to do with Turkish President Erdogan's plan to open the economy in Turkey strong ahead of elections scheduled for next year. Tourism and trade with Russia are key components of Erdogan's vision to open the economy. So I think he will maintain economic ties with Russia, notwithstanding Turkey's support to Ukraine. In the big geostrategic picture, I think Turkey supports Ukraine. Turkey sees Russia as its nemesis to the north. And I think Ankara will do everything to make sure that Ukraine is victorious at the end of the war. This is, for instance, why Turkey has provided Ukraine with drones, which have helped the Ukrainians deny Russians air superiority.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I want to talk about Erdogan's bid for re-election in a moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But first, I want to ask you, you know, it appears to be a fine line for the Turkish president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Is there the risk that at a certain point with this strategy, he could run out of road, though, and be asked to make a choice?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, Erdogan's brand has always been that he likes to play actors against each other. You know he has done this in Syria playing Russia and the U.S. against each other to achieve Turkey's goals. And I think he's also doing this now in the Black Sea area. So Turkey basically strategy is that it also wants to brand itself as the only country that can talk to both Russians and Ukrainians. And for a while, perhaps this was hype, but we saw that it came to fruition when Turkey delivered the grain corridor, allowing for wheat and grain exports from the Black Sea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It was the country that inked and clinched that deal. So I think in this regard, you could say that Turkey so far has done a good job of staying in this conflict where its policy is pro-Ukrainian but simultaneously not anti-Russian.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That's a tough act, but I think Erdogan deserves credit for managing it thus far.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And in doing so, do you think he is betting on a new polar world order?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And if he is doing so, do you think that he would be content to line up behind Russia if both Putin and Erdogan are men who manage to stay in power? I would say Erdogan and Putin perhaps have a political man crush on each other. They both like each other's style of governance. But Turkey and Russia are not allies. They have many differences. Ukraine, Russia's annexation of Crimea, Black Sea issues, East Mediterranean, Cyprus, Syria, Libya, South Caucasus, where they disagree.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So there's no way Turkey is lining up behind Russia, even in this multipolar order.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I'd say, in fact, for about a decade now, Erdogan's policy has been that he's following an autarkic foreign policy for Turkey, neither solidly with the U.S. nor solidly with other actors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I think Erdogan still sees Turkey's NATO's value to Turkey greatly and Turkey will stay in that alliance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But at the same time, it will often be a member of the alliance that does its own thing and basically guards its own interests more so than the interests of the alliance, if necessary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: its own interests more so than the interests of the alliance, if necessary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The EU's foreign policy chief, Josef Beret, welcomed the leaders of Serbia and Kosovo this morning in Brussels, ahead of high-level crisis talks to address rising tensions in the Balkans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Beret invited Kosovo's Prime Minister, Albin Kerti, and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic to the European capital in an effort to renew dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Tensions in the region escalated earlier this month after Kosovo announced plans to implement a new law forcing all residents, including Serbs living in Kosovo, to have a Kosovo ID card and license plate. Bure says he hopes both leaders will be open and flexible to find common ground. But experts doubt the talks will bring about any major progress. Well, for more on this, we can bring in Florian Biber now, a professor for

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Southeast European History and Politics at the University of Graz in Austria. Florian, great to have you with us. Now, NATO's Jens Stoltenberg has called for calm from both sides. He said that there's a peacekeeping force in Kosovo ready to intervene if necessary. Is the risk that high?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, I don't think there's a real risk of an armed conflict in Kosovo, exactly because there is a NATO mission in place, and it has been in place since 1999.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And also Serbia has no interest in an armed confrontation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So that sense, I think the NATO presence is essentially important.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But it's not that there's a conflict looming around the corner.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It is more that both sides like to sometimes play with fire and to bring up that threat of conflict rather than being interested in real conflict. So right now we've got a situation in which both Belgrade and Pristina are seeking EU membership. But of course, as you've just mentioned, Serbia still considers Kosovo as part of its territory. So what does that mean for both of them when it comes to the question of joining the bloc. Well at the end of the day neither of them can join the European Union until that relationship is settled. Kosovo is not recognized by five EU member states and that of course blocks it. It's perspective to join the EU and Serbia cannot really join without recognizing Kosovo one way or another. And this was made clear recently by German Chancellor Olaf Scholz. And this is the view of quite a number of other EU member states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So neither of them can join. But it's also doubtful whether the current Serbian government actually wants to join the European Union. It likes to talk about it, but it's not quite clear whether it's really committed to joining the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And can I ask about Russia's role in this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: To what extent has Russia actually helped keep Kosovo out of international institutions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, Serbia has lobbied hard with countries to block Kosovo's membership in international organizations. And of course, Russia and China are crucial because they are holding up U.N. membership by their presence in the U.N. Security Council.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And Serbia has thus built its good relations with Russia exactly on that issue. that if the West were to recognize Crimea or some of the breakaway territories of Georgia under Russian control, that it might reciprocate by recognizing Kosovo.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But, of course, none of that is really realistic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So from that point of view, Russia benefits from this frozen conflict in a certain way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And it's been trying to throw a wrench into the EU integration for years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So all of this is really in Russia's interest for this conflict to remain unresolved and open.
